posts.name: MSP Guy
posts.sub: /vp/'s MS Paint Deluxe Day 50: Unfortunate Edition
posts.com:
>New to these threads? Give this a quick read: https://pastebin.com/9q21PhXk (Updated: January 10th, 2023)
>Want to vote for an older Pokemon? Read this: https://pastebin.com/HvRwC4Ec (Updated: January 10th, 2023)

Can we talk about this thing for a minute? As I usually do, I went into the new games completely blind, knowing only of how the main characters look as well as the first stage starters. My first experience with this thing was seeing one of those Team Star leaders riding one, and I was incredibly hyped to get one for myself. I got the pre-evolution, wondering why it was so small but shrugged it off. Little did I know that once it did evolve, it didn't look anywhere near as cool they made it out to be. If you ask me, this is probably one of the most disappointing Pokemon in the new generation for me, raising my expectations to unreasonable levels, and as a guy that usually goes "I'll believe it when I see it", that says a lot. Because I saw it with my own eyes how amazing the ones Team Star used, and yet... Ah well, I digress.

Thank you for coming to my Ted Talk. Stay tuned for more drawings from people who also may or may not like this thing.

>Pokemon 50: Revavroom
>Hard Mode: No References or Fixes

You know the drill. Pokemon is selected at random daily, you get in this topic, you draw a Revavroom in MS Paint (or similar program), and post results.

NEW NEW NEW Checklist: https://i.imgur.com/i1mx3HT.png
Archive Under Construction...

By the way, tomorrow is Special Saturday! And it's gone!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53034784
Save and close your game. Then go to your Switch's settings and move the clock back to another time from today. Remember to keep moving your clock like this and don't let it roll over to a new day while the game is running until you get what you want. Incidentally this is how you can hold a raid over if you want to keep hosting for more than 1 day

>>53019210
Depends on what you want out of it.

It IS a competitive fighting game, despite the superficially arena fighter-esque elements: The game still has unique movelists per characters, cancels, just-frames, an attack height system, etc, and the replay value still comes from playing against other people and improving rather then having a ton of modes or single player content. It is much more Street Fighter and less Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm/DBZ budokai.

That said, for a competitive fighting game, it's approachable: There's no motion inputs, everything is either a button, a button plus a direction, two buttons, or holding and releasing a button, so at a low/starting level it's easier to pick up. The way the game handles attack heights and the whole 2d-3d shift mechanic also gives players more breathing room: The phase shift mechanic means you'll never be stuck in the corner the entire match because shifts will break you out of the 2d phase and back into the 3d phase where you're on more neutral ground, and heights exist not as a way to bypass and punish blocking, but to bypass and punish other moves during their active frames, meaning as a newbie you're not worrying about blocking high or low, rather height is a tool for YOU to use when you're on the defensive to get a reversal and hit through one of your enemy's moves.

Note this does not mean that there's less depth at a higher level of play: Some combos, tech, etc top players will be using take a lot of precise timing and dexterity (Garchomp's charge input run stance cancels are as such a lot of chomp players have to change their button layout) , and the whole phase shift mechanic is actually a huge source of an adapational and resource mangement skillgap at top play where players intentionally alter their combo composition and move choices on the fly to cause or delay shifts based on what's to their advantage; and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

ran out of space

posts.name: Anonymous

>>53019273
That's a fantastic explanation thanks. Would you say Machamp is a good character to start with?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019273
>>53019210
cont:

> and there's still height mixups even if there's not height based blocking

For example, if you have a move that bypasses and punishes move of X height, and the other player knows you have that, then they can try to use a different combo starter or meaty/on wakeup move or combo ender to try to punish you trying to punish that height

Basically, while it's said so often it's a cliche, Pokken really is "Easy to learn, hard to master": The changes Pokken makes to the fighting game template targets the sort of stuff new players tend to struggle with (motion inputs, being kept in the corner, dealing with what height to block), but those changes don't actually erase the skillgap at high level play and actually add more depth when it comes to neutral (when both players are trying to get a hit in and outwit the other player), having to adapt rather then flowchart, etc: The fact shifts break you back to a neutral state and the height system enables reversals really means there's a lot more back-and-forth where both players are in the driver's seat of the match.

But like any fighting game, you'll get out what you put in: The fun comes from learning, improving, and playing matches, not from unlocks or modes.

>>53019284
Firstly, I think worrying about "is X a good character to start with" is sort of a bad approach to getting into a fighting game: If there's a character or a game you like, start playing. If you worry about getting all the resources (not that frame data, combo guides, common punishes, etc aren't good to know) or starting with an easy character, you can easily pysche yourself out and put off just playing and learning the game/character you actually wanna play.

That being said, he actually is I think one of the easiest characters to start with. He has relatively short combos and just needs like a few stray grabs or short combos or single hits to do big damage. The drawback is he can struggle to get in to land those hits.

>>53019485
The phase shift system is entirely predictable/under the player's control, the tutorial just doesn't explain it.

3d > 2d shifts happen on basically any heavy hit or with most specials. Some lights cause it too. Basically, anything other then light projectiles will shift from 3d to 2d. This is why the game is more a 2d fighter then a 3d one: The 3d phase is basically just an additional buffer layer of neutral play.

2d > 3d shifts occur when the PSP guage is filled, and different moves, on hit, will add more or less points to that guage. Combos that hit 21 hits long also always auto-shift (as an anti-infinite mechanic), as does the universal grab (but not command grabs). However, the guage isn't in the UI, it's something you have to learn and memorize if you wanna keep track of it.

At high level play, players will alter their combos as the match goes on to always end on shifts to do optimum damage vs the shift interrupting the combo. Or they may intentionally go for combos or moves that maybe do less damage or aren't as safe, but that add less PSP, so shifts DON'T happen (thereby keeping the other player in the corner and under pressure, and maybe to get the chance to land an additional combo for more damage in that phase in the long term) or for combos that maybe don't do as much damage but do EXTRA PSP to shift faster, in case they wanna get out of pressure themselves or get the meter/health regen causing a shift gives you. Some moves also reduce or reset the PSP guage.

But like when you're starting out, I wouldn't worry about it that much: Just remember universal grabs always auto shift, heavy hits in the 3d phase shift to 2d, and the more hits you land in 2d the faster you shift to 3d. As it applies to machamp, you should also remember your command grabs do NOT add PSP, so you can use then in the 2d phase as much as you want, and wake up slap REDUCES the guage, allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>allowing you to keep the enemy in the 2d phase longer.

Just in case it's not obvious, the reason you want this is because Machamp is a lot better in the 2d phasr then the 3d phase.

Machamp is slow, and is his 3d phase projectiles suck. It's very difficult for machamp to win the field phase and cause the 3d > 2d shift, and he can't do much damage while in the 3d phase.

But even stray hits or single grabs in the 2d phase by machamp do insane damage. It's still hard to actually approach the enemy though, so once machamp IS up close in the 2d phase or especially when you've got the other character in the corner, it's in your interest to keep them there and to continue to land command grabs and rack damage up without causing a shift, most of the time, because it's hard to get back to that position.

In practice, tho, there are obviously situations where you may wanna giove up your advantagious position to land a combo rather then a command grab even if it shifts and allows the enemy to escape: Maybe you aren't comfortable yourself at the moment and just wanna take the damage you can get, maybe you'd really benefit from the extra meter causing a shift brings, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53019666
>>53019685
Also also, to be clear, the PSP guage works indepedently for both players.

If you land like 4 hits and almost max out the PSP guage, the enemy landing a hit won't shift: each person has their own guage.

And again, there is no actual visible guage you can look at, sadly: You either need to remember the PSP value of each move, or just reemerge "if I use X move Y times, it will shift" or "If I use Z combo and then land Y move, that will be enough to shift" etc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53045408
There isn't one.
Gen 1 is a great and cohesive experience but it's a buggy and unbalanced mess.
Gen 2 refines the system completely fails the region it's debuting for the false promise of a second region that is only a shadow of its former self and wrecks the level curve - plus its new mons are consistently hidden away instead of showcased.
Gen 3 introduced a bunch of cool new features but literally has too much water and doesn't even let the rival challenge the player while the remakes are full of artificial restrictions.
Gen 4 finally gets the balance about right with the physical/special split but has a terrible engine that is too slow in both its new games and the remake.
Gen 5 has an incredible story in both paired versions but its mons are 50% lazy recycles of Kantomons and it's honestly really ugly.
Gen 6 took some bold steps forward graphically, attempted another rebalance and really tries to create a child's adventure but is filled with empty promises of a second paired version that never comes and the postgame content is gutted, plus spends too much time pandering to genwunners. Its remakes are a step down from the Gen IV ones, refusing to use the third version's improvements.
Gen 7 shakes up the formula in a lot of bold ways but is entirely too easy, filled with cutscenes, and doubles down on the Kanto pandering to an extent gen 6 shied from. Its remakes are atrocious and have no redeeming features.
Gen 8 has a great idea in the Wild Area plus tries to reimagine the League but then it dives straight into Dexit, makes the game even easier than ever, and quintuples the Kanto pandering. The remakes are utterly uninspired and the pseudo-remake has a lot of good ideas but has content that expects you to have played the initial remakes first.
Gen 9 finally goes fully open world... and immediately bungles it by not having a better handle on how players level through playing.
You can't objectively rank them because the pros and the cons are subjective.

posts.com:
>>53023759
I forget that's the way of things myself since it's such a huge turn off to me, but it's true that Western art is dominated by that stuff. Honestly doesn't make sense to me to reduce every single character to the same blob in a different wig. Where's the fun in removing all character specific scenarios and traits to do the same thing over and over?

Anyway I like how a lot of Arven art draws his shirt getting a bit taut over his chest, it would be cute to see him fussing about whether he needs to apply for new uniform in a bigger size. The academy has been looking after him all this time, so he doesn't want to trouble them, but it's kinda too tight sometimes. Maybe he should just bear with it and avoid moving in ways that strain the fabric, at least until next school term. Arven's face turns red, and his lips hold tightly together after a button pops off mid class. He could die right here, fizzle into nothing, please arceus don't let them all be looking at me. The noise was so damn loud there's no way nobody heard it. He turns his head slowly and starts to sit back upright, clinging to the wayward pen he'd dropped on the floor as though it explained everything. The silent pause in Raifort's lecture feels as though it's gone on for minutes already. As her words continue, he realises no one in front has turned back. He feels the chill of sweat down his nape, suddenly aware of how tense his whole body had been and unsure how to relax and sit normally again. His eyes scan around and spot the button on the floor not far from the teacher's desk. Could he collect it covertly on the way out? Drop his pen "by accident" again? Is it even worth sewing back on? His thoughts come to an abrupt halt at a thumping on his arm. He stiffly turns in horror.
"Nice tits," whispers the strange boy sat next to him, raising an approving thumbs up. Of course Florian saw. It takes all his power not to yell.

It's more the overwhelming focus Kanto mons get. Mega Evolutions weren't too bad, but they undermined your starter and only Charizard and Mewtwo got version exclusive ones. Alolan variants only included Kanto mons even though the other five generations had plenty of entries that could have benefited from a tropical redesign, and they got the majority of the exclusive Z-moves. In Gen 8 it was just sad because all the Gigantamaxes were Gen I or Gen VIII with the exception of Garbodor (who was probably just easier to gigantamax than Muk or Weezing to get a Poison type in there) and Melmetal (who was introduced at the end of VII and filled out the Steel typing in the same way).
There's no reason why the other regions can't get some love, but excepting PLA's new Johto evolutions they never do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm excited and nervous about starting Emerald after finishing Crystal. Do you guys particularly concerned with Natures/Abilities/EVs or do you just roll with the punches?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53027277
Depends on the encounter and game state, some pokemon become liabilities with a bad nature, IVs, and movepool; like -SpA Ralts with poor SpA IVs. While fine as a Gardevoir later on due to the huge Base Stat it won't be strong enough to get there as a normal party member considering it's after the fourth badge. Then at the point where you could level it up to use it, you'll have access to other pokemon, hopefully ones with better stat distributions.

Some notable ones with the issue are
>Treecko
The worst starter in terms of early-mid game
>Poochyena
Without a decent Atk/SpA, won't do enough damage until you it before Wattson. Has Howl but is way too frail to use it. Mightyena has some utility however.
>Beautifly
Too weak and limited in moves to handle poor offensive stats
>Lombre and Nuzleaf
They need stats to balance out their awful movepools
>Ralts
As stated above

Then there's the inverse
>Mudkip and Torchic
Decent moves, coverage, and resistances balance out poor stats
>Zigzagoon
Has pick Up and gets early Headbutt which is a STAB 70 power move with a flinch chance, that with Sand-Attack, Tail Whip and Growl gives a way to set up for other pokemon
>Taillow and Wingull
Access to early Wing Attack and Water gun, respectively, are extremely useful and strong.
>Dustox
It doesn't rely on its stats as it's focused on status and support

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This one cut a little closer than it should have, but 10th game in the challenge is done

Lorelei and Bruno were dealt with Calm Mind sweeps from Slowbro, then instead of risking it through the status effects that Agatha tried to put me through, I pulled out Substitute Raticate. Deny status effects then sweep with Shadow Ball

Things didn't go as planned vs Lance, though. Blogpost incoming
>lead Butterfree to sleep Gyarados so Slowbro can setup
>Gyarados immediately wakes up
>to kill Gyarados and the incoming Dragonair but now Slowbro is at 1/3
>swap to Nidoking
>ice beam city
>freezes Dragonite
>promptly thaws and kills Nidoking with a crit Outrage
Ninetales dealt the final blow but that sucked, now I'm missing a lot of coverage and bulk vs Rival

>lead Raticate vs Pidgeot
>TWave then set up sub on Sand Attack
>kill with Return
>kill Alakazam with Shadow Ball
>Exeggutor comes in and TWave'd
>switch Slowbro and Calm Mind twice
>Ice Beam the eggs
>Gyarados comes in
>crits Bite twice
>leaves me at 20 HP
>in a panic, misplay and switch out, should have just sacrificed him for a free switch
>send out Butterfree
>Toxic then Protect/Psychic until we're both in the red
>predict his Full Restore and put him to sleep in the same turn (felt really good about this one)
>swap into Raticate and set up another sub, then kill with Return
>Charizard comes out and Fire Blasts the sub away
>swap into Ninetales and absorb his next Fire Blast with Flash Fire
>for some reason it Fire Blasts again while I confuse and slowly chip it with HP Electric
>Rhydon comes in
>can't safely switch into anything since Rock Tomb or EQ will kill
>confuse and burn before going down
>send out Raticate
>sub for safety and kill with Return

I had plenty of misplays (including not bringing a 6th to E4) but some of my predictions left me feeling really good, and I can't feel too bad by going all the way with Raticate and Butterfree lol. Rest easy, Mr. Nido and Azsakano.

Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>>53029037
I get where you're coming from but it's just excuses, we both know even if you had all your responsibilities removed, your wrist magically healed and were put in an environment where you had nothing to do for entertainment except draw you'd find a reason why you wouldn't.

It's ironic that you mention "retarded drunk child's doodles" because what do you think people think of me? It's just another way to rationalize not drawing so you don't have to face the opinions of other people.

I don't say all this to be an asshole or feed the self-deprecation cope, you can change; you just have to take the first step and trust that the resources and people you surround yourself with can help you be the best artist you can be.

It might come off as a cope to some since i'm seen as a "bad" artist but i think i've made some cool things over the years that wouldn't have existed had i not made a leap of faith.

You just have to believe that one day you're going to be able to fight in the same arena as these people. Thank you for listening to my ted talk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043105
the basic idea is
>kill all surrounding spawns without spawning target pokemon
>go stand right next to where an overworld mon will spawn, but doesnt actually spawn
>save and edge closer, restart game if you accidentally spawn it
>date skip to a clear day
>go to check summary screen of one of your pokemon and click the right thumb stick
>track the attacks
>0 = physical, 1 = special
>do this 128 times
>put this number into the program
>it will tell you how many more stick clicks you need to do in order to get to a shiny
>you need to exit the menu about 4-6 clicks early and walk forward
>once it has spawned it should be shiny when you encounter it, may need to check which pokemon you caught from the list and adjust the delay
https://github.com/LegoFigure11/swsh-overworld-rng-gui
theres a full manual on there with the tool, and theres a few youtube guides if you type in things like 'swsh overworld rng'
theres several tricks that mean you dont have to spam 4000 animations like date skipping or changing to the party menu

>pla protag dreams of their old life and family, and wakes in the night's darkness, feeling alone and suffocated under the crushing weight of their grief
>their gardevoir senses this overwhelmingly, and crawls under the covers with them
>strokes their hair, desperate to pull them away from the black hole in their heart
>protag is taken aback for some moments, but relaxes
>gazes into the slightly lambent, concerned red eyes, as gratitude and affection gushes in to fill the pit they had been falling into
>not for the first time, they realize how beautiful their pokemon is
>there wouldn't be anything wrong with...
>nobody will know...
>you let emotions sweep you past thoughts and into action, and like a runaway wave thoughtlessly crashing into the walls of a respectful sandcastle - you lean forward and lay a quick, chaste kiss on it's smooth, petal-like mouth
>you pull back and see it's eyes, wider, somehow even more focused on you. it's whole form perfectly still as it seems to work through comprehension of your action
>the feeling pulls back, leaving a salty brine of doubt in your mind
>seaweed begins to wetly gather around your heart and throat, and you start to open your mouth, to apologize to your pokemon, to gasp your shame - but your words are stalled by a slender green hand snaking it's way up your jaw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I had this dream last night. I don’t really play a lot of Pokémon, and I just come to /vp/ every now and again, so it was kinda weird to have it out of nowhere. In the dream I was out eating dinner with some friends when an old waiter came over and said “you look sad,” I didn’t really know what he was talking about as I was having a good enough time so I just said “nope, I’m doing alright.” He then gave a melancholy smile and said “would you like to see something interesting?”

At that point I was a bit weirded out, but my friends said they’d go and I figured why not. When led us to the front door of the restaurant, opened it, and we walked out into a much more colorful world. Not like somebody turned up the RGB, but colorful in a way I had forgotten. I looked down and I was 10 years old again, I looked at my friends and they were too. The world surrounding us was like the world 20 years ago, but only in the most wholesome, beautiful way. I turned around, and the restaurant had been turned into a Pokémon center and there were various pidgy’s in the trees and rustling in the bushes of other Pokémon you could just catch glimpses of. The atmosphere felt like something from gen 1 or 2, but in the most real, tangible way.

I looked up some steps to the Pokémon center, and there was the old waiter, but now he was 20 years younger. I walked up and asked him what happened, and what was this place. He said something along the lines of “you’ll only be here for a short while, enjoy it while you can.” So me and my friends ran around with the carefree attitude of a child just taking it all in, but all the while there was that sneaking anxiety of knowing we were on a time limit and this could be over soon. We had just gotten to a Pokémon themed casino, when I woke up.

I don’t know why but the whole thing has left me in a melancholy mood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many people have National Park, Azalea Town or Ecruteak City as their most emotional/nostalgic music from Gen 2, but for me it's Violet City. The way Go Ichinose used broken chords to give the illusion that more voices are being played, while adhering to the 3-poly limit of the GB soundchip, is nothing short of impressive.

Just right at the beginning of the track, you can hear the Emaj7 - D#m7 - C#m7 - Fdim - Bmaj - F#maj progression and it hits you right in the feels. And that move to the parallel minor key by using the bVII to move from the tonic to the bVI is just absolutely lovely. And let's not forget to mention that infamous IV V iii vi that is used in the B section of the track. It's just pure love to my ears.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4zyXmnvnZ0k
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OA1l8mqfld8

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53042152
If i had to compare the 2:

Crystal clear: gen 2 taken to it's limit in terms of features, giving the player as many options as possible to explore the world (variable level gyms, being able to trade evolve mons without having to connect outside, being able to progress in any direction you want, fully visible pokemon stats etc.)

Polished crystal: Gen upgraded with up to gen 7 features in a way that doesn't harm what made gen 2 good. I would recommend it for people who started with more recent games and want to experience classic johto without having to deal with obsolete/unbalanced mechanics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53041903
Instead of 2.2.0 I'd recommend picking up the latest nightly release of 3.0.0 beta from the project's GitHub, comes with more QoL features like modernized Box GUI

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal

Or you can check out the 9bit fork, which expands the possible number of Pokemon in the Pokedex beyond vanilla rom's limit of 254-ish monsters. However it's less stable than the beta from above, expect to run into glitches if you choose to play this one.

https://github.com/Rangi42/polishedcrystal/tree/9bit

>>53029640
In the context of Pokémon these types of memes and videos have far reaching consequences. Not only in shifting perceptions but also building them up as well. Vaporeon is a perfect example.

Take for example this video:
https://youtu.be/moThgJzoqIw

Something that people don't realize is that Vaporeon is still less sexualized than both Sylveon and Umbreon. Umbreon in particular is the 4th most sexualized Pokémon. But for people, and in big thanks to memes, Vaporeon remains the front face of eeveelution sexualization. The person who made that video is probably not aware of that and simply going off what the general public sees.

In truth the copypasta is very widespread that you find it acknowledged in big, open forums. No other Pokémon has that amount of meme clout. This in turn makes Vaporeon come in the fore front when it comes to Pokémon sexualization and it even helps it reach a more "normal" position. By this I mean that even in more general and tame spaces that status is acknowledged. For example being the most upvoted Pokémon in r/rule34 with over 2.4 million subscribers. Mind you the human characters decimate all the Pokémon but it's status is so strong that it can even flourish to some extend in that sort of environment. Smash or pass polls also show it doing pretty well which is an extension of that status.

In short, yes, these videos play a crucial role in shaping up perception. Generally I think the copypasta gave a face to the already strong eeveelution presence as seen in polls, eeveelutions maintain consistency in these polls which shows it's been brewing for a while.

But as much as these videos and memes reach the mainstream I still think pokephilia is something that viewed with caution. In general imageboards the human characters outperform all the Pokémon greatly.

>>53046254
Pokephilia is a blanket term for people who, well, are sexually attracted to pokemon.
It's used because, due to the diversity of pokemon, it's difficult to use one pre-existing title to define them.
Some are, I don't know, xenophiles, because they're attracted to things like Hatterene, Froslass and Gardevoir.
Some are furries (Or hmofa enjoyers or whatever they want to call themselves nowadays). This is because they're attracted to anthropomorphic designs, like Zoroark, Meowscarada, or Lucario.
Some are dogfuckers/zoophiles, because, well- you bloody guess why.
Some are... I don't even know what to call them, because they're attracted to designs like Muk or Gholdengo.
Attraction is nearly always sexual, though, as one might gather from the various /vp/ generals devoted to certain Pokemon, some exhibit romantic (Wholesome seems the wrong word) tendencies towards their chosen waifumon.
Further reading: https://youtu.be/hNqtfFXq00k

posts.com:
As a Psychicfag I hate Fairy type for being everything Psychic is but better
>same color and aesthetic
>also counters Fighting
>counters Dark and Dragon
>resist Bug
>only two weaknesses
>Tons of legendaries like psychic but much stronger
Fairies completely replace psychic's role at this point. Psychic is only carried by old gen Pokemons right now, all the new psychic types suck. Fairy was designed to counter Dragon but failed to do that in reality and actually fucks up the balance for a lot of other types, namely psychic, bug and fighting.
But what I especially hate is how GF force Fairy into everything ever since it was introduced. I've never such a type being shilled so hard. The fact that it's stupidly broken from the get go but they just make it even stronger every gen instead of nerfing it: stronger moves, strong environment and ridiculous strong Pokemons like Zacian who is quite literally the most broken thing in the game. Fairy type to me really captures the incompetence of Gamefreak as a developer and the downfall of the Pokemon franchise in general since gen 6

Gen 4+: Don't know don't care.

I do really like the system they have.
https://ydarissep.github.io/Exceeded-Pokedex/

Some times I have criticisms however.
For example, most of the Dragon Pseudo-Legendaries getting Innates that deliberately ruin the entire point of Fairy type with regards to game balance is something I don't like at all.
I don't know why the creator did this other than annoyance at Dragons being nerfed.
As well the line between what abilities are categorized as 'Abilities' and what are 'Innates' is shifty. It seems that most of the time certain traits are listed always within one category or another. But there's enough exceptions where I'm not sure if there is meant to be a pattern or not.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52985048
>>52988537
The multiple abilities/innates is something with a lot of potential, but I just do not think the way Exceeded implemented it is good.
It's just egregiously awful that so many abilities have additional effects added to them. What the fuck? It's a system built around multiple abilities. If you want multiple effects, you should put them in different abilities to mix and match instead of trying to shove it into a single ability.
I hope the Voyager hack does multiple abilities better. Are there any other hacks implementing multiple abilities?
Anyways, some of my ideas for multiple ability systems:
>separate abilities into innate and learned
>innate abilities can't be changed, reinforcing the pokemon species' identity and playstyle
>learned abilities are either earned through level up from a specific pool in a manner similar to moves, or through special conditions in a manner similar to special evolutions
>learned abilities can be passed down through breeding, allowing for new synergies with abilities not normally learned
>don't allow for a free for all ability fest, as it weakens the reinforcement of a pokemon species' identity and playstyle, as well as enable lazy and broken combos.

>>52991401
If Tyranitar can have any 3 abilities from a pool of 10 that just makes guessing which ability combo your foe's using exponentially harder unless there is literally only one good option.

I love this Innate system. Unironically the best shit I've seen in any hack in decades. Though I do wish RNG was removed from the Innates. Also can "When this Pokemon makes contact with the enemy" and "When the enemy makes contact with this Pokemon" abilities trigger from either type of Contact? A Goodra hitting a foe should apply the Gooey speed loss just like when Goodra is being hit by a foe.

Reminds me of how Effect Monsters worked in Yugioh, back when you had to choose between a strong Normal Monster without an effect (in this case, a strong pokemon with a relatively boring ability/innate set) and an Effect Monster whose effect makes up for his lack of direct power (innates designed to make the pokemon interesting, maybe even strong). And because these Innates are designed for the Pokemon, things actually feel somewhat balanced. Sure, some effects used RNG like Barrel Dragon but that was rare.

I have never actually used a Rattata on my team before. Except when I was 9 and I'd catch shitmons to use as decoys sent out to die when item-healing my Vaporeon and Charizard and Kadabra. But this game makes me want to experiment with gimmicky underpowered shitmons that could finally help my team or serve a useful niche besides "Well SOMEBODY needs to use HMs" or "Guess somebody has to be my Flying type until I can catch the one I want".

I have no clue if there's a more reliable way but from what I've found, copypasting specific variations of autotiles seemingly requires you to do the manual box selection and copy paste the tiles to wherever you need them. unfortunately bringing them to separate layers will require you to copypaste from something that has said tile on the same layer
but if you're trying to copypaste stuff onto other maps you'll have to do an entire process because for some reason the program clears the clipboard when you move over to different maps
>open a separate project that isn't the one you're currently working with
>paste the selected tiles onto whatever map is open in the second project
>do NOT deselect
>move back to the main project window
>switch maps to whatever you're trying to paste things to
>move back to project #2, making sure whatever you pasted is still selected
>copy
>move back to main project
>paste

rmxp is otherwise decently intuitive so I have no clue how they shat the bed so hard in this specific aspect

>>53020121
I tackled this issue, at least with regards to bugs, by moving then to midgame and buffing their stats. Since our games are hacks, it is important to be honest with yourself that anyone playing them has already played a lot of pokemon games, and therefore you'll want to shake things up some. The first warning sign of a hack, for me, is if the first 3 routes contain ALL early route mons (bugs, regional normal types regional bird) crammed into the same space in an 8+ pokemon encounter table
Dreadful.
Become comfortable with shifting Pokemon from places you're used to them being, and be prepared to adjust their stats a little accordingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53022834
>You're desperately trying to find holes
This is the umpteenth time you've responded to criticism with "YOU'RE JUST TRYING TO DISPROVE MY APPROACH!"
Anon, that's what discussion is - identifying talking points about a system you have proposed. The fact that the points are overwhelmingly criticism should prompt you to reflect on why those criticisms are being made, and addressing them in your response or through revision of your game mechanics. Nobody is "trying to find" holes - they are pointing out flaws that are immediately obvious.
Also
>Bug types are fixed by throwing resistances on them
Hardly. A large share of the issue is that bug types are inherently kneecapped, due to their tendency towards early game distribution and rapid evolution. For balance purposes, these things can't have 500 BST immediately available at level 10, when everything else is hovering around 400. This is half-addressed by adding a few single-stage strong bugs in the mid-late game, but doesn't address that others remain utterly useless (for example, Wormadam is a pain to try to use at any point in platinum due to how weak it is)
Redistributing bugs and rewarding them with better BSTs allows them to keep their identity of "raised quickly" while not needing to sacrifice their ability to stand up in the late game.

Also, I'm not sure how to feel about Levitate giving Magnemite and Koffing partial flying type stab. I might get yelled at for this, but might it be a better idea to create another innate called "Winged" that does the same thing as levitate and put the flying type stab on that?

Some innates are just dumb like the anti-fairy innates, and others seem like they could/should be split in two, especially something like Levitate as you mentioned which just doesn't fit certain pokemon. Magnemite and other "non-flying" levitaters should get a different kind of bonus to go with their levitate, like an electric-themed levitate or a ghostly-themed levitate for pokemon like Gengar, just giving them flying STAB is awkward.

Although the hack is treading ground most people are afraid to tread, so a bit of unbalance or theme oversight is expected, especially since he decided to tackle the entire dex at once. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53035405
>coping this hard over something so dumb
Never mentioned Gen 5 in my post either, schizo. PLA is a game with an abysmal battle system and an incredibly small amount of content variety. Once you get bored of the main gimmick, the fun is over, and that happened pretty early for a lot of us. The story is utter shit (not surprising); SV actually blew it out of the water by comparison kek. PLA also has several blatant, unnecessary features that aim to waste the player’s time (distortion-exclusives; having to reload areas because the game decided certain mon wouldn’t spawn). There are neat aspects of the game, but there are vastly overshadowed by the flaws. It feels like a simple tech demo that drags on for way too long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53036592
>HGSS
>better than GSC
Nigger, what? HGSS actually made the games worse in several areas. The level curve is a non-meme issue in HGSS because of the removed badge boosts. Combine that with a complete lack of rebalancing after the attack split, and many of the old mon are significantly worse than in GSC despite having better learn sets. Subtract some points for the sluggish Gen 4 engine, as well.

Subjectively, none of the battle sprites in HGSS hold a candle to Crystal’s, and many of the remixes miss the feel of the originals. At best, HGSS is a sidegrade to GSC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53040044
If you make a fusion and then use reverse splicers it'll swap the fusion around but still keep the ability the original fusion had.
So in this case if you make Slaking the head and Azumarill the body
>like pic related
You'll get Huge Power since only Azumarill's body can give that ability.
Then you use the reverse splicers to make Azumarill the head and Slaking the body, but you'll still get to keep Huge Power.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Recently decided to use every fully-evolved Pokemon + selected pre-evos (mostly the trades, but also Pikachu and Eevee) in the first five gen games. So far I've played through the following:

Green:
>Venusaur
>Persian
>Ninetales
>Poliwrath
>Lapras
>Magneton

All-around great team. Loved it.

Yellow:
>Pikachu
>Venusaur
>Porygon
>Marowak
>Slowbro
>Arcanine

I never used a Porygon before and I hated every fucking second of it. Other mons were decent but my two P's really dragged down the team.

Silver:
>Meganium
>Togetic
>Machoke
>Corsola
>Lugia
>Sneasel

Real meme team IMO; Lugia carried it against Red. Hafta say that watching Corsola Rollout Ho-oh and Red's Charizard to death was pretty great though. It was a terrible mon that occasionally did something great.

And currently I'm working on Crystal:
>Meganium
>Onix
>Golduck
>Wobbuffet
>Miltank
>Murkrow will join after I beat the E4

I knew that Onix was gonna suck but damn it really slithered under the bar. Psyduck was rough to use with the level curve but since it evolved it's great again. Wobbuffet pisses me the fuck off, though it's not totally useless (OHKO'd Steelix).

3.5 runs done, 600+ to go!

>>53041314
the Eternal Battle Reverie is a fucking joke. It's literally a lesser version of the Battle Frontier's Battle Castle. Why is it lesser? No level caps, no restrictions on what you can use, you can earn so many points to keep your PP replenished for days, HP restore moves can break the game, and the opponents get stale really fast considering how small the pool is both in regards to available Pokémon and usable moves. I got a 100 streak quite easily, but it took forever because you have to not only watch attack animations, but also watch your Pokémon pivot to either attack or get attacked. And the reward? Seeds, exp candy, and nuggets (money). And for what? To level Pokémon up to do more Battle Reverie? When you have a full team of level 100's with recovery moves and bulky stats, why use anything else? That 100 streak I got had me using Arceus, Cresselia, H-Decidueye, Porygon-Z, and two fillers. You can't pause your streak either and there's hardly any reason to go past 50 battles. Arceus doesn't reappear every 50 battles, it's JUST battle 50. This is not a challenge, it's a grind.

PLA is the only game I tried. Didn't buy any of the other shits on Switch.

Honestly it's funny looking back on how angry children's media producers were at the 90s anime boom. Just look at Cartoon Network around the mid-90s. Pretty much every popular original cartoon on the network did their own DBZ parody. Oh, and the only reason Powerpuff Girls was picked up was to combat the success of anime, and make a "DBZ for girls"; it was even marketed as such
https://youtu.be/q41gSqYMUzA
After the SSJ3 transformation episode had aired, it was revealed that it was one of the highest rated cartoons to ever be broadcasted on Cartoon Network, and it caused so much anger with the top creators at the network, that they did an interview with Craig McCracken and Lauren Faust, were they openly bashed the show, with similar sentiments to the ones you see in this mad magazine parody.
tl;dr, Japan stays winning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Misty winning represents something bigger than herself.
She’s more than a single character finding peace.
She represents the unresolved hopes and dreams of childhood. The dreams that never were. The hopes, not lost to a cataclysmic event, but to the ever draining hourglass of time.
Misty is the symbol of all failed ships. Your GokuxBulmas, your TaichiXSoras, your IchigoXRukias. She had been left behind, once an icon of a series, replaced by a storm of other girls with their own fanbases, all vying to be the one, but destined to die at the alter of the almighty status quo. And it was the mistyfags that had to bear the weight of non-resolution the longest.
Now, as we come to a close on this chapter in our lives, Misty returns as a symbol of hope, not just for herself, but for all Pokegirls who were destined to fail the moment they were created.

>>53045614
You should only play games if you're excited to play them. If you make it into a chore, you won't have fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53045614
If you don't care for the games anymore, there's no need to play it. Pokemon has such specific gameplay and has become its own genre in itself, that you don't need to force yourself to play it. You'll just want to or not, similar to how a Dark Souls fan just likes the games, he doesn't need to be inspired to play the games.

If you're tired of how Pokemon is being handled as a franchise, but still want to scratch that itch, check out some other monster catching games out there. I put a * to games that are more like Pokeclones if you want that exact type of gameplay.

>*Nexomon
>*Nexomon Extinction (The sequel is a better game, but it makes a lot of references to the first game)
>Monster Sanctuary
>*Monster Crown
>Monster Hunter Stories 2
>Monster Rancher 2
>Digimon World: Next Order
>Viva Piñata
>*TemTem
>Ni no Kuni Wrath of the White Witch
>Bugsnax

Your only options are Scratch (40 BP) and Fury Swipes which have a 30% chance to be slightly weaker to slightly stronger than the Tackle from your average Route 1 mon, that if you manage to hit it with 80% acc. Last time on Schizoanalysis: >>53005128

Schizoanalysis Episode 2:
-Ash finds himself on the edge of the coast in this weird multi-region. While they're all excited about it, Corphish is shown to be extra excited to "be in the sea after so long"
-I personally do not believe this to be a component of the meta-narrative being spun, but perhaps the Corphish could represent the power of "home" as Ash travels back to Kanto. Or it could tie into the narrative later as Ash sees some older released Pokemon happy in the wild. Alternatively, he could represent the excitement of the viewer to see Misty again, as that's fundementally the point of this episode.
-It's interesting to me that the Pokemon of the day, Clauncher (A water-punching Pokemon) appears in the same episode as Misty, and she's the one who'll eventually catch it.
-Misty makes her appearance by "catching" Ash with her lure, a point already discussed to death via the trailer. Of note is the feminine chime in her ENTER moment. Her trademark wink assures us that she's the same as ever.
-We see what will be changing from OP to OP every week. It's not really a whole lot, but the pokemon featured change. This further places stress on the importance of the major Pokemon in the series and how this final arc will care for them.

>>53043536
>This is where the shipping related discussion begins. It's important to note, anime shipping hints like this are usually double-entandres and must be taken with two perspectives. On one hand, an open mind willing to connect subtle dots that may seem like a fetch (red string of fate) on the other hand, the literal goings on of the episode, which are typically not so directly ABOUT romance. This gets doubly complicated with a tsundere. Don't get too butthurt or too cocky, I'm just combing for data.
-Anyway, a funny gag where PUNISHED Psyduck is clowned on (as per usual) and Pikachu embraces Misty and says "Kasumi!" in Pika-speak. Naturally, she returns the affection. Pikachu has always allowed for Tsundere Misty to show unrestricted affection in the OS.
-BIG ONE for Pokeshippers. Misty congratulates Ash on becoming champion, cites him as THE reason for her starting her own journey and that her responsibility (the Cerulean Gym) is in the hands of her sisters. This is a big deal because it eliminates her baggage at home that could get in the way of her actions in the endgame (be they ongoing adventures, a solo journey split up or even a romantic end) AND is a huge direct compliment to Ash that he compelled her to change her direction in life.
-Misty confirms the red string of fate association with her lure/fishing, which is another major bone for Pokeshippers. Those "in the know" are aware that the "red string of fate/lure" narrative is not a new one, it's a classic image among Japanese Sato/Kasu shippers. This is 100% unequivacal teasing to that crowd.
(2/?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043560
-From a Pokeshipping mindset, Clauncher represents Misty's ongoing attempt to "catch" Ash. In universe, she gets to claim semi-ownership over Clauncher because she's been trying at him first, but on a meta level, it shows an "unwillingness to give up after a failed attempt" which is big for the Sato/Kasu crowd. The fact that her first meeting with Clauncher is described as "a moment where their eyes met and she felt a spark" but the footage shows Clauncher spraying her in the face and her getting cartoonishly BTFO is a great analogue to a tsundere's mindset.
-Ironically, she is acting AS a Sato/Kasu shipper (from our universe), saying that his attacks against her is "how he shows his love". In addition she mentions "We met again and again... Could this be chance? No, it must be fate!" This is no accident. Regardless of endgame, they are purposely shipbaiting here.
-OS Ash's personality making a light appearence, he's always been one to react that way to Misty, it's funny to see him basically go "that's a bit far fetched" considering the meta implications.
-With the conflict of the episode firmly established, the two display their lures, and Ash is using Cilan's, to Misty's annoyance. This is a cute way to follow up on her token of affection as Ash teases her and she "takes the bait". Once again, serious red meat for that ship. (and could be a fun lead in to Cilan's appearence in Episode 3)
-OS music for comfy KANTOOOOO vibes
-Some classic Misty/Ash banter, the two haven't changed at all.
-The Magicarp Sub!
-Meowth remarks that the "Original Brat Girl" is back along with "Brat boy".
-Interesting that Misty gets the first catch of Clauncher, perhaps Ash wasn't correct that Cilan's lure is more effective?
-Ash gets a new ribbing nickname "The battle freak", showing that Misty can still find bantz even when Ash is champion.
(3/?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>53043571
-Team Rocket are portrayed as their usual pathetic/almost sympathetic selves, and Pokemon being food is actually touched on, very oldschool.
-Ash to Misty: "You tried to hook Clauncher and he hooked you instead" Misty to Ash "Arg, like YOU'VE even hooked anything!" the subtext grows by the minute, of course.
-Clauncher refuses to be caught in a contest of fishing, but rather, of battle and the two face off.
-Team Rocket thrusts themselves into the fray, leading to a humerous rendition of their classic catch phrase, a rude hello to Misty, Corphish saving Clauncher and becoming bros (or more?) and a quick blast off again.
-Clauncher continues to be a not so subtle allegory to a relationship, as James remarks "Oh well, there's plenty of Clauncher in the sea" as they're blasting off. Misty is horrified that they'd selfishly hurt Clauncher and cast him aside when they're done with him as well.
-Ash chooses his Corphish over Pikachu because he recognizes that Corphish has something to fight for and that matters more to him than winning or getting a new pokemon.
-Corphish and Clauncher are shown to have a loving bond with two hearts (heh, gay), this is another teasing moment as both Misty and Ash are given a side with a heart. Naturally, Misty sees it for what it is, and Ash, the eternal brick wall, sees it as a friendship.
-I like Politoad being billed as the "Guardian Diety of Ceruleon Gym", gives a nice sell of his ace status.
-Good fight, you can tell they went all out. Misty actually wins, which I think is more interesting. She earns her spot as a member of the travelling party here, she can keep up with the big dogs (albeit, with a hand tied behind his back) and that's good for her.
-Ash's reaction shows he doesn't care about losing, it was for Corphish. Clauncher seeks to teach his friend/love interest how to punch better, because it was the punch that lead to its failure.
(4/?)

>>53043575
-Misty's new Clauncher loves Ash's Corphish, and now serves as Misty's new "excuse". As a tsundere, the elimination of the bike represented her end in the OS, but now Clauncher fills that role.
-Misty feels "Psyducked" and remarks that her head hurts after seeing this, and then Psyduck responds in turn. We also see Latias, proving once and for all that episode 1 was IN FACT NOT FILLER.
-The final scene in the woods has a color palate incredibly reminiscent of Misty/Brock/Ash's goodbye in the OS, it's fitting this is how she returns.
-Misty sneakily following him is classic tsundere, she gives the Clauncher excuse, but the anime goes out of the way to make her all blushy and nervous about it. Ash sees through this and attempts to get a one up on Misty, but Pikachu gives him the excuse to relent.
-As Misty joins Ash by his side, he shows a quick moment of surprise, then a smile.

Verdict: After much contemplation, my read of the situation is that Misty has a genuine chance, but it's still to early to call. Next episode will prove a lot moving forward.

Misty is good for Ash specifically because she doesn't worship him. She keeps him in check and pushes him to be a better man than he already is.
Ash is good for Misty because he can handle her prickly nature and strike right back, and he sees through her bullshit, making sure she doesn't get too full of herself either.

Two powerful trainers with similar but slightly different goals that bring out passion and healthy drive in each other. Two long time friends that have been through a lot and require growth to even work out. That's why I like the pairing, it represents growth, not stagnation.

>>52999482
It's a character design thing. A Zoroark's ponytail, particularly the part after the bead, is in the same place you'd find a fox tail if it was attached to their keester. They were trying to be clever and weird. Hisuian Zoroark, being ghosty, ended up with a different look for its hair, but still needed some sort of tail to look complete. So they gave it a real, if rather stubby stand in.

>>53042719
These same hexagons show up in GO during your pvp/pve battles. I always dismissed it as a basic damage control barrier.
and then there's picrel. Please see the colors and the continuing hexagon motif. They're from around 2018 or so.
I figured the hexagon was an allusion to the crystal structure, but I think it's a nod that the derangement has been around longer than we thought.
I have no firm theories, just sharing an example of how pervasive this motif is. GO could have been the testing ground for the ritual, or a replication of an already successful ritual/offering. If I look as the games as virtual altars, it makes more sense.
